courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Introduction to Architecture
courses.description: ARCH1001 explores creative processes, the realms of imagination, and art and design practices in viewing, experiencing, reading and, ultimately, making architectural form. Skills of representation and fabrication are introduced in the context of the development of each student’s capacity to observe, interpret and translate design concepts into physical form.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Learning to do architecture involves a particular kind of learning. As a mind wishing and willing to take on the challenges and responsibilities of “architecting” we must become a student of the ways in which the minds of fellow architects think and work.*

The aim is to expose the students to a precise and rich set of tools and armatures; a spectrum of design skills and transformations to introduce the practice of architecture as a design process and language that activates, mediates and politicizes the built environment and its subjects.
courses.course_syllabus: Group projects, individual assignments, critiques, discussions, research and studio sessions will provide students an opportunity to work through issues and ideas within a social, cultural and personal context.
courses.required_readings:
1) Francis D.K. Ching. Architecture: Form, Space and Order. 2th ed. Wiley, 2014.
2) Paul Laseau. Graphic Thinking for Architects and Designers. Wiley, 2001.
courses.recommended_readings:
1) Rudolf Arnheim. Art and Visual Perception. 2nd ed. University of California Press, 1974.
2) Francis D.K. Ching. Architectural Graphics. 5th ed. Wiley, 2009.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Understanding Cities

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description:
This course introduces fundamental ways of understanding a city by looking at its architecture and physical environment as sites of collective living, production, exchange and consumption. From the production of art to the collection of rubbish, the course aims to explore the architectural and urban dimensions of cities (from material to cultural and symbolic) through salient topics such as city and war, city and power, city and trade, energy, transportation, housing, and entertainment.
Referring to prominent cities in the world including Hong Kong, we will touch on significant urban themes such as local / global, memory / envisioning, development / sustainability.
Topics include: What is a city for? How do cities work? How are cities made and remade? What role do architects and others play in the design, planning, maintenance and imagining of cities?
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2111.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- a basic understanding of the way cities work in terms of their architectural and physical aspects

- an awareness of central themes of urban culture and their built manifestations

- an ability to discuss and formulate points of view on important urban issues by reference to appropriate cases

- fundamental skills to transfer the issues presented to other cities and cultures
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces fundamental ways of understanding a city by looking at its architecture and physical environment as sites of collective living, production, exchange and consumption. Important historical and contemporary examples will be used to explain the city through its layers. From the production of art to the collection of rubbish, the course aims to explore the architectural and urban dimensions of cities (from material to cultural and symbolic) through salient topics such as city and war, city and power, city and trade, energy, circulation (transportation), housing, entertainment (pleasure and sin), etc.

Referring to Hong Kong as well as other prominent cities in the world, we will touch on significant urban issues such as those between local / global, memory / envisioning, development / sustainability. Through lectures, seminars and group discussions, we will consider these topics by asking key questions such as: What is a city for? How do cities work? How are cities made and remade? What role do architects and others play in the design, planning, maintenance and imagining of cities?

This course aims to provide students with: a basic understanding of the way cities work in terms of their architectural and physical aspects; an awareness of central themes of urban culture and their built manifestations; an ability to discuss and formulate points of view on important urban issues by reference to appropriate cases.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Visual Studies
courses.description: This course introduces visual media, examining how its history and ideas can help develop our critical understanding of spatial design. The course offers an overview of the subject for those with little or no visual art + design background and is intended to provide a sense of visual literacy. The course is designed to develop skills of observation, interpretation and creativity, as well as giving a strong intellectual grounding in visual thinking, and the form, meaning and content of visual media.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Demonstrate a familiarity with major historical movements in art and be able to explain how art relates to its time and culture.
• Demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the elements of art, principles of design, and the creative process.
• Demonstrate an understanding and awareness of the various art media.
• Demonstrate an appreciation of the role of art in society as a means to expand their outlook and develop the expression of their own ideas in various visual media and forms.
courses.course_syllabus: The course consists of 9 topics arranged in three groups in terms of drawing media: line, tone and color. The first group focuses on three basic formal elements as shape, volume and space in addition to basic drawing systems. The second group focuses on figure and ground relationship, light and shade, and plasticity. The third group focuses on abstract color, perceived color and texture.
courses.required_readings:
1. Douglas Cooper, Drawing and perceiving, Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1992
2. Gu Daqing, Design and Visual Perception, China Architecture and Building Press, 2002
3. Frank Ching, Drawing a creative process, Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1990
4. Betty Edwards, Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain, Fontana, 1982
5. Kimon Nicolaides, The Natural Way to Draw, Houghton Mifflin Company Boston, 1941
6. Claudia Betti and Teel Sale, Drawing —A Contemporary Approach, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich College Publication, 1992

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Experiencing Architecture

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description:
(UGEC1016 is double-coded with ARCH1320.)

The course provides a general outline to architecture. The aim is to introduce architecture as a cultural phenomenon. The course will increase the student's awareness of the built environment as it exists all around. It examines a variety of spatial experiences encountered in exemplary places and buildings. The scope of the course is not limited to buildings alone, but includes cities and landscapes as extensions of architecture. The course introduces a range of topics, including the historical, symbolic, aesthetic, functional, cultural and green aspects of architecture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC1016 and ARCH2111.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To comprehend the discipline of architecture in relation to the broader contexts of history, culture and civilization.

To remember the key concepts and some significant works of architecture.

To analyze the relationship between architecture, city, and landscape, cultural memory.

To comprehend the design and building process of architecture.

To enrich students with direct dialogue with the architects/designers who have created the architecture.

To apply skills for clear expression in written and oral presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course introduces a number of topics related to the conceptual and aesthetic aspects of architecture. Among the topics introduced will be the following:

* Introduction of Architectural Vocabulary

* A Brief History of Hong Kong Architecture

* Architecture through the Ages

* Architecture and Culture

* Architecture and Heritage

* Green Architecture

* The Design Process

* The Building Process and Architectural Practice

* China New Architecture

The course format involves regular lecture sessions, with occasional discussion sessions and short group presentations. The course may also include occasional field trips/excursions to selected sites in Hong Kong as well as some workshop exercises.

1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review

02. Post 97 public architecture, Hong Kong, page 7-11. MCCM (NA4425 H85 H68 2005)

03. 'isms: Understanding Architectural Styles by Jermy Melvin, Herbert Press London (NA200 M45 2005)

02. The Death and Life of Great American Cities by Jane Jacobs

03. the City Shaped - Urban Patterns and Meanings Through History by Spiro Kostof

courses.description: The aim of this introductory course is to introduce students to the field of architectural design through studio learning. The course provides opportunities to explore fundamental design issues relating to architecture: space, habitation, construction, and urbanization. Traditional hand drawing and model-making skills are taught integrated with design exercises.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have demonstrated basic understanding of fundamental issues related to architectural design such as the notion of space, form, use, site, and construction, acquired knowledge of architectural design in relation to space, form, use, site, and construction at a fundamental level, mastered basic model-making and hand drawing skills to conceive, study, explore, articulate, and present design ideas, and developed a method of work from conception to realization at a fundamental level of complexity.
courses.course_syllabus: The course consists of four precisely defined projects: pavilion, room, hall and campus. Each project deals with a particular design issue and method of work: space, habitation, construction, and urbanization.

courses.description: This course is a continuation of ARCH2111. The main focus is placed on the further development of a working method through which space concept is conceived though working with model materials, and crystallized with the consideration of habitation and further materialized through the means of building materials and construction. In addition to traditional hand drawing and model making skills, students begin to learn 2D CAD drawing and 3D modeling.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ARCH2111.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have demonstrated a better understanding of fundamental issues related to architectural design such as the notion of space, form, use, site, and construction, acquired further knowledge on design development from concept to building, mastered basic computer aided design skills to conceive, study, explore, articulate, and present design ideas, and developed a method of work from conception to realization at an appropriate level of complexity.
courses.course_syllabus: The course is a design of a small building consisting of four developing phases: concept, organization, materiality, and realization.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Digital Media

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: Computational design, as an approach to architecture, applies the science of design problem solving to space, analysis, representation, interactivity, and buildability in the real world. Understanding how to create, manage and manipulate data is of paramount importance for young designers entering into a digital industry. The ability to manipulate formulae is a powerful tool for digital designers. It is an invaluable asset in architectural expression and lays the foundation for building a set of dynamic drawing tools. This course guides students through the rudiments of computational design, and gradually builds up a vocabulary of operations necessary to control elements within a three-dimensional environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH3222
courses.learning_outcomes:
Participants who complete this course will have a broad knowledge of various architectural
design computing instruments and techniques that they can use in architectural design. They will have
sufficient practical skills allowing them to immediately apply in design studios and other courses.
Mobility, fabrication and building information modelling are new fields to which this course will
contribute with basic knowledge to facility the needs of current architectural environments.
courses.course_syllabus: Digital design media, methods of communications, and design computing in architecture are the core topics addressed in this course. Digital instruments for drawing, drafting, image processing, 3D modelling and visualization, layout, (Internet-) publishing and fabrication are introduced through lectures covering theoretical concepts and practical skill building exercises. These learning outcomes are applied and transferred to problems and situations arising from the Architectural Design Studio.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architecture Fundamentals
courses.description: This course is to introduce basic issues in architecture. The course covers four main topics: space, habitation, construction and urbanization. Space is the main objective of architectural design. Habitation refers to basic issues relating to how people use space and interact with physical environment. Construction refers to structure, material, construction and tectonic expression. Urbanization refers to urban fabric and open space. Students gain knowledge about these four topics through observing, analysing and recording the specific phenomenon from the living environment. The course is conducted in parallel with the Introduction to Architectural Design I (Design Studio U1) (ARCH2111) in the same sequence so that design and study could enhance with each other.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH4426
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have mastered a set of basic vocabularies to describe architectural phenomena, acquired basic skills to discover architectural knowledge through direct observation, and demonstrated a preliminary understanding about aspects of architecture.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is conducted in a combination of lecture, reading, observation, tutorial, and presentation. Students will work on four assignments in groups and at the end of the term each student will write a final essay based on the assignments, literature reading and reflections on studio work.

1. Space—Space defining elements, types of space definition, and complexity of space definition
2. Habitation—Body, gesture, movement, activity and program
3. Construction—Material, components, construction, structure, and tectonics
4. Urbanization—Urban fabrics, open space, materialization of urban space
courses.required_readings: Steen Eiler Rasmussen, Experiencing Architecture, Cambridge: M.I.T. Press, 1962.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Pierre von Meiss, Elements of Architecture: from form to place, London & New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1990.
2. Franck Ching, Architecture, form, space & order, New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1979.
3. Jonathan Block Friedman, Creation in space: a course in the fundamentals of architecture, Dubuque, Iowa: Kendall/Hunt, c1989-

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural History and Theory I: Asian Architecture
courses.description: This course stresses the importance of understanding the history and theory associated with architectural form and space. It will reach this goal by identifying and investigating historic works of architecture from China and other Asian cultures that survive to the present. These investigations, which will employ the methods that historians currently use to analyse architecture, will provide students with the means to study other building types and architectural dynamics in further courses ARCH3322 and ARCH3323 of the architectural history and theory sequence.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH3321
courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand the way in which architecture expresses the culture of the society in which it is a part.
To be aware of the universality of such architectural phenomenon.
To be able to discern the architectural language of a locality in whole and in parts and the mutation of the language with different building type and geographical region.
To be able to analyze architectural expressions in the context of the culture in which the buildings are produced.
To be aware of the continuum of architectural form and meaning.
courses.course_syllabus: The course will deal primarily with the history of Chinese architecture. It will be centered on Beijing as the focus to explore the various cultural on the architectural forms. As the capital city of China for more than 600 years, Beijing is a rich deposit of various building types, from the grandest to the humblest. These are the examples for the study of Chinese architectural. By extension, examples from outside Beijing will also be drawn, including those from East Asia. It is structured into two main parts: Part I will deal with the architectural language of China and East Asia, and Part II will deal with specific examples of Chinese buildings within the historical development. It will be divided into three thematic sections relating to forms of human and social activities: dwelling, religious pursuits and political manifestations. These are the most essential activities of the human world, individually and collectively, in the traditional period of time. Here, the language of the architectural form will be overlaid with historical and cultural contexts so that the perception of these forms and meaning ascribed to them by their users will be explored.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Cultural Contexts I
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the history and theory of Western architecture from Classical Greece to contemporary times. It is primarily concerned with four themes: (1) concepts of geometry and proportion, (2) concepts of architectural representation, (3) professionalism and the institutionalization of architecture, and (4) the relationship between architecture and engineering since the 19th century. Students will acquire fundamental knowledge and terms of reference in preparation for the subsequent courses ARCH2323 and ARCH3321 of the architectural history and theory sequence.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH3322
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will have a basic knowledge of a general outline of Western architecture, and develop detailed knowledge of some buildings and architects; an ability to formulate critique in writing and in visual presentation; an awareness of how to connect historical and theoretical knowledge to design.
courses.course_syllabus: In this course, students will explore ideas and practices that shape our architectural heritage - from the Greek conception of ideal beauty to the nineteenth-century idea of time and history. This course attempts to understand how, in various times in the past, these ideas manifest themselves in intellectual and technical levels through individual works of art and architecture; and how ideas are connected across places, times, and types of works
courses.required_readings:
Spiro Kostof, A History of Architecture, Settings and Rituals (New York and Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1985 and 1995).
Hanno-Walter Kruft, A History of Architectural Theory from Vitruvius to the Present (New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 1994).
Christian Norberg-Schulz, Meaning in Western Architecture (New York: Rizzoli, 1980).
Marvin Trachtenberg and Isabelle Hyman, Architecture, from Prehistory to Postmodernity (New York: H. N. Abrams, 2001), second edition.
courses.recommended_readings:
Richard Sennett, Flesh and Stone, The Body and the City in Western Civilization (New York and London: W. W, Norton & Company, 1994)
E. H. Gombrich, The Story of Art (London: Phaidon, 1995).
John Summerson, Architecture in Britain 1530 to 1830 (Harmondsworth, Middlesex: Penguin Books, 1970).
Rudolf Wittkower, Art and Architecture in Italy, 1600-1750, revised by Joseph Connors and Jennifer Montagu (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1999).

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Cultural Contexts II
courses.description: This course stresses the importance of understanding architectural history and theory with respect to culture and context. There is a specific focus on 20th-century architects and buildings, a range of key architects’ philosophies and approaches and the relationship between architecture and the visual arts. Students will study architecture with respect to historical continuities and ruptures, as well as explore the unity of forms and diversity of spatial practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH4323
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will have a general understanding and appreciation of fundamental ideas, movements and key figures and works of modern architecture; an awareness of the broader contexts of Modernist history and culture; have good knowledge on selected buildings, architects and related writings through their course works; have a decent ability to interpret and critique works of modern architecture in writing; an awareness of the applicability of architectural history and theory to the tasks of design.
courses.course_syllabus: Outlines the history and theory of modern architecture through significant works of the 20th century. Works of Modern Architecture are examined as artifacts of their time, and as designed objects in their own right and for their own qualities. Focus will be on how individual works relate to important manifestoes, critical writings, parallel developments in the arts, as well as their cultural, and intellectual historical contexts.
courses.required_readings:
Alan Colquhoun, Modern Architecture
William Curtis, Modern Architecture Since 1900
Kenneth Frampton, Modern Architecture, a Critical History
courses.recommended_readings:
History:

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Building Technology I: Materials and Construction
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of building structure and explores the relationship of structure to architectural design. Examines the characteristics and performance of a few basic structural assemblies, such as trusses, arch and cable systems, and frames. Examples of building structures from around the world are used to illustrate the relationship between material, structure and form.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH3423
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understand the significance of structure in architecture.
• Understand the structural design process and the role of the engineer in contemporary practice.
• Be aware of the scope of basic structural systems and types, their behavior and performance characteristics, and their potential for contributing to architectural form.
• Understand the basic physics of structures and its relation to structural form and behavior.
• Be able to select and configure a few basic structural systems (systems of vertical support, horizontal span, lateral force resisting systems, etc.) at the level of preliminary design.
• Understand the importance of detailing in the design development of building structure.
courses.course_syllabus: Emphasizing the role of structure in architecture, the course is organized according to the four basic categories of structure described by Engel (1968). Each type is studied to understand the physical performance characteristics based on the action of forces as well as the design parameters determined by economy, life safety and architectural context. Schematic, preliminary design exercises employing physical behavior models, graphic statics form-finding and standard member selection design charts provide experience in the selection and configuration of a few basic structural systems.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Building Technology II: Materials and Construction

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: Studies materials and construction based on precedent analysis and design application. Introduces an appreciation and exploration of the essential knowledge of materials and construction, with particular reference to application in the context of Hong Kong and the region - highrise, high-density and high-humidity. Emphasis on the process of integrating knowledge and field observation related to architectural and construction practice. Discover the nature, performance, limitations and developments of various construction and material systems, including structural systems, envelope systems, finishes systems.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To provide the basic knowledge framework in materials and construction and help students see how such integrates with architectural design.
2. To provide a continuation for further studies in Building Technology curriculum.
3. To help students enter into the architectural profession, with emphasis on their appreciation of tectonic and technical Issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is designed for studies in materials and construction with an approach based on operation practices and observation exercises. It will introduce to first-year architectural students an appreciation and exploration of the essential knowledge of basic model/building materials and their potential application.
The course emphasizes on the process of integrating knowledge framework, observation ability and exploration skill related to architectural and construction practice. Students will be introduced to the importance of tectonic issues and the ethics of using materials. Students will be encouraged to discover the processing, performance and potential of given building materials and construction systems.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural Design Studio I
courses.description: Architectural Design Studio I to IV (ARCH3113, 3114, 4115, 4116) form a sequence of project-based professional courses in architecture. This course, through different projects, will allow students to learn the process of building design and hone their design skill by either focusing on specific aspects of architecture or addressing various factors that influence the architectural form. These factors include activities, environmental technology, sustainable design and urban setting. Students are also required to demonstrate an understanding of structure, construction system and materials through their design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ARCH2112.
courses.learning_outcomes: This studio grounds architectural creation on the investigation of use and program in consideration of cultural context. After taking this course students will have learned to engage in a process which evolves from the awareness of their own experience of space, to the observation of human activities and the understanding of the influence of uses and their cultivation and the implicit forming of space. They would be able to develop an architectural concept through the analysis of the program, the study of relevant precedents, and the exploration of scenarios of use and sequencing of spaces, and to use this concept as a guideline for the organization of space and the formal expression of the project.
courses.course_syllabus:
- To observe and document personal experience of and human activities in space
- To understand program in terms of culture, function, and space requirements
- To design spaces that relate to human scale and dimension
- To organize space based on program, scenarios of use and movement
- To conceptualize architecture with regard to the use of space: both functional and symbolic
- To identify and effectively resolve functional and space planning requirements in building design
- To understand the relationship between program, architectural concept, and built form
- To analyse and use relevant precedents in the design development of habitable space

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural Design Studio II
courses.description: Architectural Design Studio I to IV (ARCH3113, 3114, 4115, 4116) form a sequence of project-based professional courses in architecture. This course, through different projects, will allow students to learn the process of building design and hone their design skill by either focusing on specific aspects of architecture or addressing various factors that influence the architectural form. These factors include activities, environmental technology, sustainable design and urban setting. Students are also required to demonstrate an understanding of structure, construction system and materials through their design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ARCH3113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Observe site-specific climatic environments and understand their impact on building form and architectural design.
• Understand the architectural implications of basic structural and building envelope systems and accommodate their functional parameters in both integrated and appropriate design strategies.
• Perceive craft in relation to the processes of design, fabrication and construction.
• Reinforce and further develop visual and verbal skills necessary for explaining and clarifying design ideas.
courses.course_syllabus:
Architectural design and natural forces.
The basic forces in nature; gravity, light, wind, air movement, and temperature, can serve as primary generators of form and architectural intention. Addressing both the functional and aesthetic criteria of design is seen as compatible and contributing to a legible, non-derivative expression of form.

Building technologies: catalyst for inspiration and basis for architectural strategy.
Materials and methods of construction play a key role in defining both the logic and the visual character of a building. The interplay between computer-controlled fabrication (mass customization), collaborative digital modeling (BIM) and integrated component assembly is driving many of the most innovative architectural designs today. However, in a world that is refocusing on the benefits of sustainable design, old and proven materials and methods of construction, seen in a new light, may also provide new inspiration for achieving low energy/low carbon footprint building design.

Making: material, fabrication, connection and assembly.
Building is an act of making. Making involves both an activity of the mind (thought) and the physical action (skill) of fabricating and constructing. This studio views craft in construction as a design activity in itself. Decisions about the choice of materials, the methods used for shaping/forming, and the techniques employed for connecting/joining are all considered part of the design process. To better understand the implications on built form, the studio engages students in the design and construction of functional objects at full scale.

Performance evaluation in the design process.
All building design is based to some degree on performance criteria. These criteria are either explicit or implicit in the building program. In order to predict and measure performance in a hypothetical or un-built design, some form of simulation is required. The studio employs several forms of simulation in design including physical modeling, full-scale prototype testing and various types of computer modeling to simulate the effects of structural loadings, airflow, lighting, and thermal conditions.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Digital Design Methods
courses.description: Computational design, as an approach to architecture, applies the science of design problem solving to space, analysis, representation, interactivity, and buildability in the real world. Understanding how to create, manage and manipulate data is of paramount importance for young designers entering into a digital industry. The ability to manipulate formulae is a powerful tool for digital designers. It is an invaluable asset in architectural expression and lays the foundation for building a set of dynamic drawing tools. This course guides students through the rudiments of computational design, and gradually builds up a vocabulary of operations necessary to control elements within a three-dimensional environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2222
courses.learning_outcomes:
Participants who complete this course will have a broad knowledge of various architectural
design computing instruments and techniques that they can use in architectural design. They will have
sufficient practical skills allowing them to immediately apply in design studios and other courses.
Mobility, fabrication and building information modelling are new fields to which this course will
contribute with basic knowledge to facility the needs of current architectural environments.
courses.course_syllabus: Digital design media, methods of communications, and design computing in architecture are the core topics addressed in this course. Digital instruments for drawing, drafting, image processing, 3D modelling and visualization, layout, (Internet-) publishing and fabrication are introduced through lectures covering theoretical concepts and practical skill building exercises. These learning outcomes are applied and transferred to problems and situations arising from the Architectural Design Studio.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architecture and Global Culture
courses.description: This course stresses the importance of understanding the history and theory of architecture in relation to global cultures and contexts. As the culmination of three-course sequence in architectural history and theory, the course will reach this goal by identifying and investigating historic and modern works of architecture from cultures around the world (including Asian and Chinese). These investigations will employ the methods that historians currently use to analyse architecture. It will provide students with the means to study building types and architectural dynamics of different places while drawing out relationships between past and present.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2321
courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand the way in which architecture expresses the culture of the society in which it is a part.
To be aware of the universality of such architectural phenomenon.
To be able to discern the architectural language of a locality in whole and in parts and the mutation of the language with different building type and geographical region.
To be able to analyze architectural expressions in the context of the culture in which the buildings are produced.
To be aware of the continuum of architectural form and meaning.
courses.course_syllabus: The course will deal primarily with the history of Chinese architecture. It will be centered on Beijing as the focus to explore the various cultural on the architectural forms. As the capital city of China for more than 600 years, Beijing is a rich deposit of various building types, from the grandest to the humblest. These are the examples for the study of Chinese architectural. By extension, examples from outside Beijing will also be drawn, including those from East Asia. It is structured into two main parts: Part I will deal with the architectural language of China and East Asia, and Part II will deal with specific examples of Chinese buildings within the historical development. It will be divided into three thematic sections relating to forms of human and social activities: dwelling, religious pursuits and political manifestations. These are the most essential activities of the human world, individually and collectively, in the traditional period of time. Here, the language of the architectural form will be overlaid with historical and cultural contexts so that the perception of these forms and meaning ascribed to them by their users will be explored.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural History and Theory II: Western Architecture
courses.description: In this course, students will explore ideas and practices that shaped of our architectural heritage. From the Greek conception of ideal beauty to the nineteenth-century idea of time and history, intellectual formulations are both exciting and practical; they inspire us and give us techniques for work. In this course, we will attempt to understand how, in various times in the past, these ideas manifest themselves in architectural and technical levels through individual works of art and architecture; we will also see how ideas are connected across places, times, and types of works. Above all, this course conveys an urgent agenda to develop critical engagement with the present in thoughtful ways in our architectural and urban interventions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2322
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will have a basic knowledge of a general outline of Western architecture, and develop detailed knowledge of some buildings and architects; an ability to formulate critique in writing and in visual presentation; an awareness of how to connect historical and theoretical knowledge to design.
courses.course_syllabus: In this course, students will explore ideas and practices that shape our architectural heritage - from the Greek conception of ideal beauty to the nineteenth-century idea of time and history. This course attempts to understand how, in various times in the past, these ideas manifest themselves in intellectual and technical levels through individual works of art and architecture; and how ideas are connected across places, times, and types of works

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Building Technology II: Building Structure
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of building structure and explores the relationship of structure to architectural design. Examines the characteristics and performance of a few basic structural assemblies, such as trusses, arch and cable systems, and frames. Examples of building structures from around the world are used to illustrate the relationship between material, structure and form.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2413
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understand the significance of structure in architecture.
• Understand the structural design process and the role of the engineer in contemporary practice.
• Be aware of the scope of basic structural systems and types, their behavior and performance characteristics, and their potential for contributing to architectural form.
• Understand the basic physics of structures and its relation to structural form and behavior.
• Be able to select and configure a few basic structural systems (systems of vertical support, horizontal span, lateral force resisting systems, etc.) at the level of preliminary design.
• Understand the importance of detailing in the design development of building structure..
courses.course_syllabus: Emphasizing the role of structure in architecture, the course is organized according to the four basic categories of structure described by Engel (1968). Each type is studied to understand the physical performance characteristics based on the action of forces as well as the design parameters determined by economy, life safety and architectural context. Schematic, preliminary design exercises employing physical behavior models, graphic statics form-finding and standard member selection design charts provide experience in the selection and configuration of a few basic structural systems.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Building Technology III: Environmental Technology

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of passive environmental design. It examines the effect on buildings and their occupants of environmental conditions of light, temperature, air movement and sound. Case studies are used to review both traditional and current approaches of representative building types in more depth.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have demonstrated basic understanding of fundamental issues related to the environmental design of architecture. They will acquire knowledge of the subject with sufficient exposure and at a suitable level so that they will be able to appreciate the topical issues of climate, human bio-meteorology and the design of indoor and outdoor environment for human habitation. This will allow the design of better buildings, further study, or to pursue a career in the building design and construction industry.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduces the fundamental concepts of passive environmental design. Examines the effect on buildings and their occupants of environmental conditions of light, temperature, air movement, and sound. Case studies are used to reviews both traditional and current approaches of representative building types in more depth.

• To understand the significances of environmental design in architecture.

• To understand and to be able to apply appropriate environmental strategies in different climatic and urban contexts to achieve human comfort.

• To have a basic understanding of the building physics related to passive environmental design.

• To appreciate the application and integration of passive environmental design in architectural works.

• To develop skills in conducting a systematic investigation into the subject and presenting the results in a clear and convincing manner.
courses.required_readings: Brown G Z and Dekay M, (2001) Sun, Wind and Light, 2nd edition, John Wiley and Sons Inc., New York.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Land and City
courses.description: This course introduces students to important theories and practices associated with the urban built environment that affects and is affected by various socioeconomic and environmental processes. It provides an understanding of the physical aspects of the city around and beyond architecture to allow the students to think critically about the spatial phenomena of contemporary urbanism. By reading and analyzing various components of the urban built environment, students learn to develop systematic approaches to understanding the relationship between spatial design and the city holistically across multiple spatial scales. The course is organized into three interrelated modules: (1) ‘Urban Morphology’ reviews classic and contemporary discourses pertaining to how urban built environment is to be designed; (2) ‘Urban Landscape’ introduces the increasingly important field of landscape architecture in urban development; (3) ‘Urban Sustainability’ explores theories and practices associated with the ideology of sustainable or eco cities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH4721
courses.learning_outcomes: The course aims for the students to gain an understanding of the disciplines of urban design and landscape architecture that are increasingly important in architectural education. After taking this course, students are expected to be able to articulate what urban design and landscape architecture involve and their relationships with architecture, and how together these design practices contribute to urban sustainability.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is an introduction to the study of cities, and a required course for final year undergraduate architecture students. What are the forms of city? What are the physical attributes of different forms? What shape cities? The course refers to The City Shaped by Spiro Kostof as textbook, and draws upon a broader list of other readings. It includes a number of lectures to examine the form and process of cities. The course material focuses on five predominant city forms in history namely: the organic pattern, the grid, city as diagram, the grand manner of cities, and skyscraper cities. Using Hong Kong as a site of investigation, students will examine the physical attributes and historical process of particular places, and critically evaluate them against the form of cities.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural Design Studio III
courses.description: Architectural Design Studio I to IV (ARCH3113, 3114, 4115, 4116) form a sequence of project-based professional courses in architecture. This course, through different projects, will allow students to learn the process of building design and hone their design skill by either focusing on specific aspects of architecture or addressing various factors that influences the architectural form. These factors include activities, environmental technology, sustainable design and urban setting. Students are also required to demonstrate an understanding of structure, construction system and materials through their design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ARCH3114.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will be able to develop an ability to observe, document, and interpret conditions of a site; the skill to achieve building/site strategies and contextual response; an awareness to recognize the importance of creating common spaces and public expressions; the architectural knowledge to speculate on and design with an urban strategy.
courses.course_syllabus: This studio investigates contextual response and place-making in architecture. Using specific sites in Hong Kong as a context, the studio searches for the design of architecture and settings so as to respond to: 1) the disintegration of urban fabric; 2) the ineffective use of space; and 3) the lack of a coherent urban strategic plan. Behind the studio is an attempt to use architectural design as a vehicle to explore alternative urban strategies to current architectural and planning practices in Hong Kong.
courses.required_readings:
Benevolo, Leonardo, The history of the city
Lynch, Kevin, The Image of the city
Rossi, Aldo, The architecture of the city

Koolhaas, Rem, Delirious New York: a retroactive manifesto for Manhattan,
Krier, Rob, Potsdam: the making of a town
Rowe, Colin & Koetter, Fred, Collage city

courses.description: Architectural Design Studio I to IV (ARCH3113, 3114, 4115, 4116) form a sequence of project-based professional courses in architecture. This course, through different projects, will allow students to learn the process of building design and hone their design skill by either focusing on specific aspects of architecture or addressing various factors that influences the architectural form. These factors include activities, environmental technology, sustainable design and urban setting. Students are also required to demonstrate an understanding of structure, construction system and materials through their design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: ARCH4115.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will be able to design a building that demonstrates an understanding of the interdependence of various systems and explores meaningful relationships that can lead to expression and clarity of form. Furthermore, an understanding of the integration of the three principal building systems: structure, envelope and interior will be demonstrated in a comprehensive building design project.
courses.course_syllabus: The intention behind comprehensive building is to guide students in the design of a building that addresses most of the issues common to a medium size building. Some aspects of the design may remain at a schematic level, such as the structural system, the site development or certain building services, such as fire code compliance (the design should demonstrate an understanding of egress requirements and other basic fire safety design rules). Other areas should indicate a level of development beyond previous studio work. The accommodation of program area requirements should be met and the spatial composition of the plan resolved to a higher level than previous work (compare to U5). The use and functions of the major space should be carefully studied and articulated. The design should satisfy these fundamental requirements while also expressing a design concept that has clarity and a consistent formal order.

courses.title: Topical Studies in Design Theory
courses.description: This elective course is offered to investigate the design theory of architecture. Each specific elective is designed to allow students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. There will be different number of electives offered with specific course description for students to choose from, designated as 4131A/B/C/D, etc Students are allowed to take these courses at most twice, provided that the course contents are different, and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of the current discourse on the design theory. Students will also gain an understanding of the significance of new approaches and their impact on design theory.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in design theory.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural History and Theory III: Modern Architecture
courses.description: The three-course sequence in architectural history and theory culminates in the analysis of architectural works produced in conjunction with changes in the 20th and 21st centuries. In these works - office buildings, shopping centres, airports, multifunctional urban complexes, etc. - students will examine what occurred, architecturally and globally, as a result of the historical changes they have studied in the first two courses of the sequence. In so doing, students will be well-grounded in understanding historical continuities and ruptures, as well as the unity of forms and diversity of solutions. They will also be better prepared to analyse with a degree of impartiality the historical and theoretical dynamics associated with works of architecture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH2323
courses.learning_outcomes: Students who completed this course will have a general understanding and appreciation of fundamental ideas, movements and key figures and works of modern architecture; an awareness of the broader contexts of Modernist history and culture; have good knowledge on selected buildings, architects and related writings through their course works; have a decent ability to interpret and critique works of modern architecture in writing; an awareness of the applicability of architectural history and theory to the tasks of design.
courses.course_syllabus: Outlines the history and theory of modern architecture through significant works of the 20th century. Works of Modern Architecture are examined as artifacts of their time, and as designed objects in their own right and for their own qualities. Focus will be on how individual works relate to important manifestoes, critical writings, parallel developments in the arts, as well as their cultural, and intellectual historical contexts.

courses.subject: ARCH

courses.description: This course consolidates principles established in ARCH2422, 3423 and 3424 through the integration of structure, envelop, mechanical, and interior systems. Deals with theory of interrelationship among various systems. Examines possibilities and implications of building systems on design. Introduces the concepts of sustainability in design. Explores topical issues of related contemporary thoughts and architectural practice.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have demonstrated basic understanding of fundamental issues related to the integration of various building systems and acquired knowledge of some aspects of sustainable design at a conceptual level that can be applied to studio projects or architectural practice.
courses.course_syllabus: This course consolidates the fundamentals established in ARCH2422, ARCH3423 and ARCH3424 through an integrative approach to building technology in the design and construction of buildings. It explores the integration of site, building form, structure, enclosure, services and interior space planning. In addition, sustainable design and building information modeling BIM practices are examined. A core aspect of the course is the inter-relationship of systems in achieving a high-performance building design. Case studies serve to illustrate both conceptual planning and practice.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in Professional Practice Management
courses.description: The course connects the arena of the architecture school with the domain of architectural practice. The approach is to broaden the student's appreciation of the culture within which architecture is formed. The student is given a working appreciation of the contractual, ethical, economic, legal, and socio-communal issues that relate to the profession. In particular the course introduces the student to the concept of professionalism; that is, the professional person's position in, and responsibilities towards, society. Within this context the emphasis of the course is on the role of the architect working in relationship with others. Generally the course prepares the student for a role in the architect's office during the practical experience year.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Land and City
courses.description: This course introduces students to important theories and practices associated with the urban built environment that affects and is affected by various socioeconomic and environmental processes. It provides an understanding of the physical aspects of the city around and beyond architecture to allow the students to think critically about the spatial phenomena of contemporary urbanism. By reading and analyzing various components of the urban built environment, students learn to develop systematic approaches to understanding the relationship between spatial design and the city holistically across multiple spatial scales. The course is organized into three interrelated modules: (1) ‘Urban Morphology’ reviews classic and contemporary discourses pertaining to how urban built environment is to be designed; (2) ‘Urban Landscape’ introduces the increasingly important field of landscape architecture in urban development; (3) ‘Urban Sustainability’ explores theories and practices associated with the ideology of sustainable or eco cities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ARCH3721
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. The course aims for the students to gain an understanding of the disciplines of urban design and landscape architecture that are increasingly important in architectural education. After taking this course, students are expected to be able to articulate what urban design and landscape architecture involve and their relationships with architecture, and how together these design practices contribute to urban sustainability.

2. The course aims to nurture critical thinking into urban physical development. Students are expected to develop the ability to read and analyze urban built environment in both systematic and innovative ways.

What are the physical attributes of different forms? What shape cities? The course refers to The City Shaped by Spiro Kostof as textbook, and draws upon a broader list of other readings. It includes a number of lectures to examine the form and process of cities. The course material focuses on five predominant city forms in history namely: the organic pattern, the grid, city as diagram, the grand manner of cities, and skyscraper cities. Using Hong Kong as a site of investigation, students will examine the physical attributes and historical process of particular places, and critically evaluate them against the form of cities.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies of Cities
courses.description: This elective course is offered to investigate urban studies. Each specific elective is designed to allow students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. There will be different number of electives offered with specific course description for students to choose from, designated as 4731A/B/C/D, etc. Students are allowed to take these courses at most twice, provided that the course contents are different, and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of the current discourse on cities. Students will also gain an understanding of the significance of new approaches and their impact on cities.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will explore ideas on informal architecture and urbanism. In early societies, spatial orders were evolved out of the necessities of daily patterns. People dwelled under shelters, exchanged at crossroads, played on open fields, and defended within walls. Settlements, then cities, were shaped and rebuilt according to prescribed orders of divinity or democracy. Architecture and its extending urbanism, thus, take forms to accommodate, to contain and even to express design ideas. But when forms are substituting spaces, and formalities are replacing meanings, architecture without its proper engagement of the people’s cultures and their associated ethos will become a convention, or simply an art of composition.

In places under the pressure of rapid development, like most Asian cities, where transplantations of formal architecture and urbanism colonize prominent locations, core values of local communities have been diluted. In fact, there is much to be appreciated when we ‘go to the crowds’ and learn from them how to cohabit with the conditions. Recently there has been a social awareness of the local culture and its direct application in design. And if we examine the ways of living and see how they are transforming spaces to be informal but meaningful, our environment will be more colorful and humanized, just like David Adjaye noted, “…A similar notion could be applied to the way that vines work with walls in a symbiotic way; they start to destabilize the wall and eventually the two cohabit. And co-dependency becomes a requirement of this cohabitation.”

In this perspective, we will put forward critical issues on urban phenomenon, organic growth, collective memory, public engagement and community building. Cases will be introduced, students’ initiatives will be encouraged and guest speakers from Asian cities will be invited to confer further ideas.

courses.description: The year-long Design Studio forms the core of the Master of Architecture programme, with each course directly connected with the School’s design, societal and environmental agenda. Students are expected to design an architectural proposal from concept to final representation, through careful consideration to scale, context, tectonics, material and technology. The course offers a wide range of topics including: Urbanism, Building Technology, History & Theory, Digital Design and Design & Practice. It is geared towards developing innovative forms of competence and enabling students to work on different architectural fields, from the design of urban masterplans to individual buildings, from landscape redevelopments to adaptive reuse of existing buildings, from sustainable building designs to application of the latest building technologies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
Develop complex architectural propositions, with a rigorous understanding of contextual and environmental issues, contemporary technological challenges, historical and theoretical meanings and programmatic requirements.
Develop the ability to be part of an innovative intellectual climate, promoting design research exploration together with the ability to work collaboratively in teams.
Develop the communication skills related to technical, spatial and conceptual aspects of design through drawings, models as well as verbal communication.
Develop the ability to pursue and develop a design project through research exploration.
Develop a design working methodology that is consistent with professional and ethical standards.
Understand the social responsibilities of design, consistent with the School’s 25 year history.
courses.course_syllabus: This studio course addresses particular issues in architectural design. Part I consists of topic research and site analysis. Part II is the development of a building design proposal that addresses the studio topic or theme.

courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of design theory. Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. Each semester, there will be different sections of electives offered with specific course descriptions for students to choose from.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Architecture and BSSc (Architectural Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of current issues and debates in the field of design theory. Students will also gain an understanding of the relevance of design theory on architectural form and design.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in design theory.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Advanced Computational Design Methods
courses.description: This CORE course exposes students to an iterative approach to design problem solving with computation and automation tools. Students will gain exposure to computational design methods, applications, and hardware systems in the context of contemporary and future approaches to architectural design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: The topics in this course refer to issues in architectural design, theory, and practice methods underpinned by contemporary and emerging technologies with computational design, artificial intelligence., computer numerically controlled (CNC) fabrication, robotics, and others. The course will provide students with skills to understand complex forces that shape architectural design, critical methods, fabrication, and technologies to synthesize architectural design works. Using a design thinking approach, students will gain computational literacy and familiarity with technologies to articulate the relationship between design abstraction and physical translation, engage in an iterative approach toward design that navigates observation, analysis, ideation, prototyping, testing, and reflection with design tools.
courses.course_syllabus: The core content / syllabus should be covered by the course and selected topics may be added by any individual course instructor. Topics in this course will refer to issues in architectural design, theory, and practice methods framed by technology adoption, exploration, and virtuosity.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in Computational Design
courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of computational design. Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. Each semester, there will be different sections of electives offered with specific course descriptions for students to choose from.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Architecture and BSSc (Architectural Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper awareness of current trends and new tools in the field of computational design. Students will also gain an understanding of the significance of current developments in computational design on architectural form and design.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in computational design.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Architectural Theory and Criticism
courses.description: The primary intention is to draw together the many diverse strands of twentieth-century architectural theory into a synoptic overview intellectually accessible to M.Arch. students. Achieving this will necessitate study not only of canonic architectural theories emanating from Europe, America and Asia, but also of general theory in those other fields from which they so often derive. Relevance will be established through studies of applications or outcomes of such theories discernible in the cultural complexities of architecture of Hong Kong. This course’s main deliverable will be a written dissertation to comply with the requirements of accredited bodies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Able to analyze critical writing and buildings, and to draw out the ideas behind them.
- Able to discuss major concepts of architectural theory and criticism from the mid twentieth century.
- Able to complement the design studio through the influential projects and ideas discussed in class.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics are Metropolis, Simplicity, Avant Garde, Complexity, Context, Phenomenon, Performance, Representation, Topology and Projective.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in History, Theory and Criticism

meetings.instructor: Professor CHUNG Wang Leung Thomas Tommy

courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of history, theory and criticism. Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. Each semester, there will be different sections of electives offered with specific course descriptions for students to choose from.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of Master of Architecture and BSSc (Architectural Studies)
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of current issues and debates in the area of architectural history and theory and how they impact architectural form and design. Students will also develop skill in the analysis and criticism of works of architecture.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in history, theory and criticism.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Advanced Building Systems I
courses.description: This course develops an advanced understanding of building technology in view of the growing global complexities of built environments. The course, offered as a required course for post-graduate level Architecture majors, enables students to master design thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach, apply it to an understanding of topical architectural issues. Lectures are arranged to advance building technology topics in structural, sustainable and environmental systems design, providing a holistic and integrated focus to the design and making of buildings. Case studies from contemporary practice and significant historic works will be used to illustrate building system typologies that contribute to an understanding of the relationship between design intention and built form. Course topics will also emphasize integrated and sustainable strategies in tall building design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will equip students with a sound basis from which to identify, understand, and coordinate building environmental systems. We will focus on an architect’s role and responsibility for environmental systems as a fully integrated part of a sustainable building fabric.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics are
1) Systems Overview
2) Evaluation
3) Air | Heat | Cooling
4) HVAC Systems
5) Water
6) Fire Safety
7) Electrical Services System
8) Lifts + Escalators
9) Daylight
10) Façade Integration
11) Artificial Light
12) Acoustics
13) User Interface & POE
courses.required_readings:
Selected readings from books and journals will be issued for reading on a weekly basis in support of lecture material and coursework. A number of the readings will be selected from the following:
Lechner, N. Heating, Cooling, Lighting – Sustainable Design Methods for Architects pub. John Wiley & Sons New Jersey 2008
Marston Fitch, J. American Building - The Environmental Forces that Shape It pub. Oxford University Press New York 1999
Grondzik et al Mechanical & Electrical Equipment for Buildings pub. John Wiley & Sons New Jersey 2010
Lam, W. Perception & Lighting as Form Givers for Architecture pub. Van Nostrand Reinhold New York 1992
Hegger (et al) Energy Manual Sustainable Architecture pub. Birkhauser, Basel 2008
Bougdah, H & Sharples, S. Environmental, Technology and Sustainability pub. Taylor & Francis New York 2010

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Advanced Building Systems II
courses.description: This course develops an advanced understanding of an integrated design process in view of the growing global complexities of built environments. The course, offered as a required course for post-graduate level Architecture majors, enables students to master design-thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach, apply it to an understanding of topical architectural issues. Building on the substantial knowledge base in building technology (structural, sustainable and environmental systems design), the course advances the students’ relevant understanding of professional practice issues to provide a holistic and integrated focus to the design and making of buildings. Students form groups to actively engage in a “creative” design process that leads to an innovative proposal that fulfills a list of design goals. Upon completing this course, students will have acquired design skills and practical problem-solving skills in integrated building technology that are directly transferrable to further design work in their future careers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Able to identify common structural and building construction systems and describe their characteristics as well as their advantages and disadvantages.
- Understanding of hi-rise building design and the major developments that shaped its evolution.
- Able to identify and configure schematically basic foundation support structures.
- Able to select and develop schematically a structural scheme for a proposed building design. This would include but not be limited to the following: primary structure, type and size of major spanning elements, floor and roof framing, lateral force resisting system, and foundation structure. These components to be developed in parallel with a studio building design project.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course include foundations, lateral forces, tall buildings (evolution, systems, case studies), horizontal span systems and building envelope.

courses.title: Topical Studies in Professional Practice Management
courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of professional practice management. courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have acquired deeper understanding of professional issues related to the selected topics of Professional Practice Management, face-to-face dialogue and personal sharing with experts, acquired knowledge of aspects of the subjects with exposure at a suitable level to allow further study in this subject or to pursue career development.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in professional practice management.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in Landscapes and Environmental Design
courses.description: This course examines the key intellectual currents and seminal projects that underpin the theories and practices of modern landscape design and its related disciplines. The course begins by exploring the professionalization of landscape architecture in Europe and America at the turn of the 20th century, alongside emergent design thinking in diverse geopolitical contexts both within and outside the “West.” The course also considers the various ways in which the concept of “landscape” is used across different fields, including architecture, planning, urban design and conservation, as well as in anthropology, geography, and environmental humanities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) Become familiar with the key intellectual currents and seminal works in landscape design in the 20th century.

b) Cultivate a critical awareness of the complex and interconnected forces that shape natural and human-made landscapes across various geographical and cultural contexts.

c) Understand the fundamentals of scholarly research and learn how to analyze diverse source materials for academic writing.

d) Enhance the ability to communicate and collaborate effectively with colleagues through presentations, debates, and discussions.

e) Reflect on the personal and professional ethics in design practice.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the Course Outline.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in Sustainable Design
courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of sustainable design. Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. Each semester, there will be different sections of electives offered with specific course descriptions for students to choose from.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of the current discourse on sustainable design. Students will gain an appreciation of the significance of low carbon footprint, energy conservation, embodied energy, passive design strategies, etc., and their impact on the built environment.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in sustainable design.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Urban History and Theory
courses.description: This course examines the main ideas, histories and theories of the city through specific local and international examples from significant historical, political, geographical and environmental periods and aspects. Important themes and debates in urban design and planning will be critically explored to understand the relationship between the urban forms, the culture of cities and their sustainable development. In particular, the way urban forms have been used and reinterpreted, adapted and challenged by different social, economic and political contexts. Exemplary design projects and planning policies are investigated in view of their relationship to contexts and their impacts on communities and the environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture and MSc in Urban Design;Mutually exclusive to URBD5703
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will provide students with skills to understand complex forces that shape cities, and introduces critical methods and tools to describe and theorize the urban processes that influence the built environment. Using a themed approach and in-depth case studies, students will learn to articulate the relationship between visual and physical form of the urban environment and urban settings, processes and contexts in different perspectives, styles and methods of inquiry.
courses.course_syllabus: This course examines the main ideas, histories and theories of the city through specific local and international examples from significant historical, political, geographical and environmental periods and aspects. Important themes and debates in urban design and planning will be critically explored to understand the relationship between the urban forms, the culture of cities and their sustainable development. In particular, the way urban forms have been used and reinterpreted, adapted and challenged by different social, economic and political contexts. Exemplary design projects and planning policies are investigated in view of their relationship to contexts and their impacts on communities and the environment.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation, individual feedback on papers, external examiner report
