Carmona, M. & Tiesdell, S. (eds.) (2007) Urban design reader.

Chuihua J.C. [et al.] (2001) Great Leap Forward.

Harvey, D. (1985) Consciousness and the urban experience.

Koolhaas, R. (1994) Delirious New York.

Larice, M. & Macdonald, E. (eds.) (2007) The urban design reader

Low, S.M. (1999), Theorizing the city.

Miles, M. [et al.] (2000) The city cultures reader.

Mumford, L. (1989) The city in history.

Mumford, L. (1997) The culture of cities.

Parker, S (2004), Urban theory and the urban experience: encountering the city.

Robbins E. & El-Khoury, R. (eds) (2004) Shaping the city: studies in history, theory and urban design

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Topical Studies in Urbanism
courses.description: These elective courses investigate topics and issues in the specific field of urban design. Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field. Each semester, there will be different sections of electives offered with specific course descriptions for students to choose from.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture, BSSc (Architectural Studies) and MSc in Urban Design
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired a deeper understanding of the current discourse on the design of communities and cities. Students will also gain an understanding of the significance of new approaches and their impact on urban and communal design.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in urbanism.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Conservation
courses.description: The history of a locality is often defined by its culture and the built manifestations of that culture. The preservation of the architectural heritage of a culture is an indication of the importance that culture placed on its past. The trend in the developed world today is to preserve historical monuments, historic district, tangible and intangible heritage as much as possible. In Asia, conservation has a checkered history. For China and Hong Kong, architectural conservation is at the early stages of development. Much have been learned and much have to be done. This course is designed to introduce the basic concepts and practices in conservation with a particular emphasis on conservation practices in Hong Kong and the region. It will serve as the foundation for further development of interest and skill in conservation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: Each specific elective is designed to allow the students to gain in-depth knowledge and ability to discourse or execute the theory and practice of the particular field.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in architectural conservation.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Materials and Construction in Architectural Conservation
courses.description: Every building tradition has its unique construction system employing primarily local materials and craftsmanship. This course will introduce to the students various regional traditions, such as the timber tradition in East Asia, stone and brick tradition both ingenious and imported to East Asia and the 20th century tradition in the region with local and imported materials. Issues and techniques in employing these materials and construction systems in historic periods will be addressed. Site visit will be a feature of this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand the properties of various materials used in historic buildings in the region.
2. To understand the various construction systems used in the region.
3. To be able to analyse the materials and construction system used in a historic building.
4. To understand the issues involved in the conservation of historic buildings in the aspects of materials and construction.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in construction in architectural conservation.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Issues in Heritage Conservation
courses.description: This course will address the pertinent and current issues facing heritage conservation in the region. The format will be a heritage forum with invited speakers articulating the current discourses and issues which might include conservation legislature frameworks, cultural values of built heritage, grass-root advocacy, heritage tourism, sustainability, revitalization of heritage sites, or issues facing specific projects in urban renewal, conservation of national monuments, and other design projects. The key activities of the course are discussions and dialogues for understanding and critique of the current practices in conservation of built heritage in Hong Kong, China and the region, as well as to explore the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To be aware of the current issues involved in heritage conservation.
2. To understand the complex situation and contestation between different stake holders in conservation.
3. To understand the mechanism for successful heritage conservation.
4. To be able to critically analyze conservation efforts.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in heritage conservation.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Hong Kong Architectural History (Culture of Building)

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description:
This course looks at the architectural development and planning in Hong Kong through historical periods, examining both traditional Chinese settlements and colonial urban development. Issues such as culture and society, land and building regulations, rural and urban conditions, as well as building techniques will be covered. At the end of the course, student shall be able to identify the architectural style, spatial quality, layout, function, and decoration of buildings of different types and periods. The types of buildings that will be covered include the following three categories:
- Chinese traditional buildings;- Buildings with colonial influence from late nineteenth to early twentieth centuries;- Building with modern building technique from 1910-1970
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in this course refer to contemporary issues in Hong Kong architectural history (culture of building).
courses.recommended_readings:
Carl T. Smith, A Sense of History: Studies in the Social and Urban History of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong Educational Publishing Company, 1995
Cheung, K. H. Ferdinand, “Tenement Buildings: In Light of their Origin”, in HKIA Journal, Hong Kong, PACE Publishing, Issue No. 24 2nd Quarter, 2000.
Chiu, Y.N. John., A Survey and Classification of Tenement Buildings along Queen’s Road – Hollywood Road., Hong Kong, the University of Hong Kong, 1970.
Hong Kong Going and Gone: Western Victoria, Hong Kong, Hong Kong Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society, 1980.
Hong Kong (China) Buildings Department. Building Development and Control in Hong Kong, Hong Kong: Buildings Department, 1999.
Katherine Mattock, This is Hong Kong:The Story of Governement House, Hong Kong, Hong Kong Government Printer

courses.title: Topical Studies in Design, Theory, and Practice Methods
courses.description: This module-based course is offered to investigate novel design methods and theories for architecture. There will be a different number of electives offered with specific course descriptions, designated as section A/ B/ C/ D etc. Students may take a maximum of three of these courses in place of a single three-credit elective. However, students may not take the same course section more than once in any particular semester.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture and Bachelor of Social Science in Architectural Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will provide students with skills to understand complex forces that shape architectural design, introduces critical methods and tools to describe, theorise, emulate, or synthesize creative works pertaining to the built environment. Using a themed approach and in-depth studies, students will learn to articulate the relationship between visual and physical form, processes, and context in different perspectives, styles, and methods of inquiry.
courses.course_syllabus:
The core content/ syllabus should be covered by all sections of the same course and selected topics may be added by individual course teacher.

Topics in this course refer to issues in architectural design, theory, and practice methods.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Develop complex architectural propositions, with a rigorous understanding of contextual and environmental issues, contemporary technological challenges, historical and theoretical meanings and programmatic requirements.
Develop the ability to be part of an innovative intellectual climate, promoting design research exploration together with the ability to work collaboratively in teams.
Develop the communication skills related to technical, spatial and conceptual aspects of design through drawings, models as well as verbal communication.
Develop the ability to pursue and develop a design project through research exploration.
Develop a design working methodology that is consistent with professional and ethical standards.
Understand the social responsibilities of design, consistent with the School’s 25 year history.
courses.course_syllabus: This studio course addresses particular issues in architectural design. Part I consists of topic research and site analysis. Part II is the development of a building design proposal that addresses the studio topic or theme.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Advanced Architectural Design Studio II (B)
courses.description: The Design Studio forms the core of the Master of Architecture programme, with each course directly connected with the School’s design, societal and environmental agenda. Students are expected to design an architectural proposal from concept to final representation, through careful consideration to scale, context, tectonics, material and technology. The course offers a wide range of topics including: Urbanism, Building Technology, History & Theory, Digital Design and Design & Practice. It is geared towards developing innovative forms of competence and enabling students to work on different architectural fields, from the design of urban masterplans to individual buildings, from landscape redevelopments to adaptive reuse of existing buildings, from sustainable building designs to application of the latest building technologies.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Professional Practice and Management
courses.description: This course is offered to Master of Architecture students who have completed their first degree in architecture and their year-out practical training. While in line with the HKIA/ARB professional practice assessment requirements, this course is meant to prepare the students in the handling of professional matters once they graduate from the MArch programme, to help them integrate into the profession and begin their professional training with an aim of obtaining professional qualification in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon the completion of the course, students will have acquired advanced understanding of professional issues related to the subjects such as the Role of Architects, Building Contract, Professional Conduct and Practice outside Hong Kong, acquired knowledge of aspects of the subjects with exposure at a suitable level to allow professional development.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics are:
1) Tendering Procedure and Contractual Arrangement
2) Small Practices in Hong Kong
3) Practice in South East Asian Countries
4) Practice in Mainland China and Overseas
5) Ethics and Corruption Prevention in the Building Industry
6) Practice in Registered General Building Contractors (RGBC)
7) Project Execution in Practice
8) Practice in Green Building Design

courses.description: Discussion of current research and research traditions in the various domains of architecture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
Term 1: Students should demonstrate ability to: (1) understand different research agendas and how they might be relevant to their own research, and (2) frame an abstract for a conference paper in a way that relates some aspects of their own research to the thematics of an academic conference.

Term 2: Students should be able to demonstrate ability to (1) prepare and deliver a conference presentation and gain some experience in conference (or seminar) organization, and (2) demonstrate a capacity to give critical and argued comments on the research work of other students.
courses.course_syllabus: Discussion of current research and research traditions in the various domains of architecture.
courses.feedback_evaluation: To be negotiated between the teacher and the student.
courses.required_readings: To be recommended by the supervisor/course instructor
courses.recommended_readings: To be recommended by the supervisor/course instructor

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Research Methods I
courses.description: An introduction to research methods common to the various domains of architecture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should

1. Understand the basics of research methods in architecture and its allied environmental disciplines.
2. Able to define the scope of a research thesis and frame relevant research questions.
3. Able to locate different types of sources for a research thesis.
4. Develop a critical intellectual position as required for academic research.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to help students define the scope of their thesis, frame relevant research questions and arguments, and become familiar with the types and usage of reference materials for their thesis projects. Course assignments will enable students to articulate a critical intellectual position through the development of a research prospectus, thereby deepening their understanding of the significant role of research in architecture and the built environment. The course will include lectures, discussions, and other in-class activities.

courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Research Methods II
courses.description: This course helps students develop a capacity to operationalize concepts in their research designs and contextualize their projects within the broader academic landscape.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil-PhD Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should

1. Demonstrate the ability to operationalize theoretical concepts in their research designs.
2. Contextualize their research projects within the broader academic landscape.
3. Become familiar with varied techniques of data collection.
4. Develop an appreciation for diverse methodological perspectives.
courses.course_syllabus: Building on the research training received in Research Methods I, this course will help students learn how to operationalize theoretical concepts in research designs and become familiar with a variety of data collection techniques. The course aims to enhance students’ intellectual and methodological skills, fostering a strong connection between theory and research that will support their ongoing thesis development. As part of the course requirements, students will actively participate in the regular research seminar series organized by the School of Architecture, enriching their learning experience through engagement with scholarly debates and discussions.
